skill.name: astropy
skill.description: Comprehensive Python library for astronomy and astrophysics. This skill should be used when working with astronomical data including celestial coordinates, physical units, FITS files, cosmological calculations, time systems, tables, world coordinate systems (WCS), and astronomical data analysis. Use when tasks involve coordinate transformations, unit conversions, FITS file manipulation, cosmological distance calculations, time scale conversions, or astronomical data processing.

security_audit.summary: The skill is documentation and usage examples for the Astropy Python library. No executable code, system access, or network behavior is defined in the files.

content.user_title: Learn Astropy workflows for astronomy data
content.value_statement: Astronomical data tasks are complex and error prone. This skill provides clear Astropy guidance for coordinates, units, time, FITS, tables, and cosmology.
actual_capabilities: Explain coordinate transformations using SkyCoord and common frames
Guide unit conversions and equivalencies with astropy.units
Describe FITS file reading, headers, and HDU access
Outline cosmology distance and time calculations with Planck18
Explain table I O, joins, and filtering with astropy.table
Describe WCS pixel to world conversions from FITS headers
limitations: Requires Astropy installed in the user environment
Does not execute code or access data automatically
Accuracy depends on correct input frames, units, and metadata
Does not replace scientific validation or peer review

prompt_templates.title: Convert RA Dec
prompt_templates.prompt: Show how to convert RA 10.5 deg and Dec 41.2 deg from ICRS to Galactic using Astropy.

prompt_templates.title: Read FITS header
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain how to open a FITS file and read EXPTIME and FILTER keywords.

prompt_templates.title: Cosmology distances
prompt_templates.prompt: Using Planck18, outline how to compute luminosity and angular diameter distances for z=1.5.

prompt_templates.title: WCS pixel mapping
prompt_templates.prompt: Describe how to convert pixel coordinates to sky coordinates using a FITS WCS header.

output_examples.input: Convert RA 05h23m34.5s Dec -69d45m22s from ICRS to Galactic and report l and b.
output: Create a SkyCoord in ICRS with the given RA and Dec
Report l and b in degrees from the galactic coordinates

best_practices: Attach units to all quantities before calculations
Use context managers when opening FITS files
Verify coordinate frames and time scales explicitly
anti_patterns: Assuming default time scales without checking
Using WCS transforms without validating headers

faq.question: What environments are compatible?
faq.answer: Any Python environment with Astropy installed works, including notebooks and CLI scripts.

faq.question: What are the limits of this skill?
faq.answer: It provides guidance and examples but does not run code or access your data automatically.

faq.question: Can it integrate with my pipeline?
faq.answer: Yes, it can guide Astropy usage in your existing Python pipeline and data formats.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: The skill content does not include data collection or network exfiltration behavior.

faq.question: What if results look wrong?
faq.answer: Check units, frames, time scales, and FITS headers for mismatches or missing metadata.

faq.question: How does this compare to generic Python help?
faq.answer: It focuses on Astropy modules, astronomy formats, and domain specific best practices.
